text:
Hello this is chef John from
FoodWishes.com

Today I'm going to show you my
special garlic and ginger

Clifton Springs chicken wings.
And uh... why it's called that?

Well you're gonna have to read the post.
Let's get started!

First we need a chicken wing
anatomy session.

That top art there, the part that attaches
to the chicken, is called the drum.

The middle part is called the flat,
and the end is call the tip.
So we're gonna break is in 3 pieces.

You're gonna go with your knife
between the drum and the flat,

until you can kind of where that joint hinges.
Just cut it until you can see the joint.

Okay, see that? Now that's kind of
a ball and socket type joint.

And put your knife right in between
and it will go through like butter.

So the other end, the, uhh, what's
called the tip, youâ€™re gonna cut that

off right at the joint again.
Just move until you can see it

And we're gonna throw away the
tips 'cause we don't want 'em.

But you can make soups with those.
So there's 5 pounds of chicken wings,

separated into the drum and flat, and
i'm gonna stop same drum and flat now.

We're gonna season that with some black
pepper and salt because I'm not going

to season my flour, I want the
seasoning on the chicken.

Got some Frank's hot sauce, that's
the official chicken wing hot sauce

We're going to put a few tablespoons
of that.
Give that a toss.

And then, we are going to pour in
just a little bit of vegetable oil.

And I'm gonna use a grape seed oil.
You want something neutral, okay,

something that doesn't really
have any flavor.

And we're gonna coat those real lightly
with the oil.

Now what we're going to do here, it
we're gonna coat these in flour and

oven fry them.
So we're gonna fry these on a oiled

pan, so put some aluminum foil on
them, 2 half sheet pans.

Alright, I'm gonna put a nice rounded cup
of plain flour in a garbage bag,

or in a large plastic bag. I'm gonna
dump in my 5 pounds of wings.

Alright I'm gonna bunch it up
so it doesn't fly all over my face,
and now I'm gonna shake it.

And yes, shake and back,
very funny.

Alright we're going to shake this until
they're all coated. You can kind of feel

in there, and, uhh, just make sure
they're all really well mixed so there's

no like wet spots on 'em,
and there you go.

Those are now floured, or dredged,
as they say in culinary school.

You're gonna take those out, and again I'm
gonna show you one pan at a time here,

but you're gonna do 2 sheet pans,
nice and evenly spaced.

Now the pan is oiled, as you saw, but you
also want to spray some of that oil

onto the chicken wing itself so it fry's
nice and crisp.

These are gonna go in a hot oven,
okay 400 degrees,

and those are gonna bake for a half-hour,
and then we're gonna turn 'em over.

Now they're not gonna look
very good at this point,
alright, but don't be scared.

they've got a half hour to go,
the fat, and the connective tissue

is starting to break down the chicken
wing, that's gonna make them sticky

and start to caramelize and get
crispy in the oven.

So while those are going for the
second thirty minutes,

we're gonna make our ginger
garlic sauce, which, strangely

enough has some crushed garlic,
and some ginger.

So that's up to you, I like a lot
of both.  I'm gonna put in a

big spoon of hot sauce, which is
optional, but I think you should put it.

That's, uhh, sambol, which is an
asian hot sauce.

I've got a half a cup of rice vinegar,
very important.

And a half a cup of packed
brown sugar.

And just to maybe a teaspoon,
a splash of soy.

Alright so that's just to bring out the
flavor in that glaze, and give this a
taste when it  comes to a boil.

And you can adjust the seasonings
if you want.
And as soon as it boiled,

and as soon as you're happy
with how it tastes,
turn it off.

Alright, now, our chicken is out of the
oven, it's been an hour, half-hour each side.

They're nice and crispy, and really,
really, really nice texture.

You're gonna pour over half the
sauce, over half the wings.

You're going to toss it in the bowl,
and they should be coated evenly.

Now you don't have to do the flick toss
here, I'm just showing off, you can just

move 'em around with a spatula or
with the tongs. Alright, so we're gonna

pour those back on the sheet pan,
and just let 'em cool because people will

go to grab these cause they smell
and look so delicious,

there's nothing worse than third
degree garlic, ginger burns.

Okay, let these cool for about
5 to 10 minutes,

the sauce will soak into
th coating,

it will stay kinda gooey, and crispy,
and crunchy
and uh... oh so good!

Alright, so that's Clifton Springs
chicken wings.

Put 'em on your serving tray
and us crack open a couple beers,

do not dip these in blue cheese
with celery stick please
Please don't do that.

Anyway, go to the site and get
more info if necessary, and as always, enjoy!
